intro: Thyrsanthus, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Myrtaceae. It is native to New Zealand and consists of several species, including Thyrsanthus heterophyllus and Thyrsanthus tetraphyllus. These plants are characterized by their narrow, strap-like leaves and showy, clustered inflorescences. They are often found in coastal and montane habitats, thriving in well-drained soils. Thyrsanthus species are valued for their ornamental qualities and have historical uses by Māori for weaving and other crafts.
